description.narrative: The Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 10 recognizes the developmental contribution of remittances to reduce inequality within and among countries, which also notes the persistent issue of high transfer costs. In line with SDG target 10.c established by 2030, to reduce to less than 3 percent the transaction costs of migrant remittances and eliminate remittances corridors with costs higher than 5 percent.The main rationale for supporting the planned intervention are the following. - Remittances are an essential source of capital for many low-income households, -Digital finance can lower the cost of remittances, and- Cutting remittances costs by 3.5 percent on average can lift 30 million people out of poverty. In 2018, remittances to low and middle-income countries increased by 9.6 percent, to reach $529 billion, which exceeded the economies’ inflows of Foreign Direct Investment (FDI). In similar manner, remittances are increasingly important to Africa mainly because of its positive role in stabilizing the economy of receiving countries, poverty alleviation and financial inclusion of the poor. Remittances represent the most stable source of flow and have been the largest source of international financial flow to Africa since 2010, accounting for about a third of total external financial assistance to the continent.United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) via its Regional Innovation Hub , based in Dakar, Senegal has applied to the Embassy of Sweden in Addis Ababa for funding of 55 million SEK to carry out the programme entitled "Remittances for Development in Africa 2019-2022. The ultimate goal of the programme is to contribute to regional harmonization of remittances policies and availability of affordable, accessible, reliable, and tailored digital remittances and financial products to migrants and their families in Africa towards their economic inclusion, financial resilience and reduced inequality.The planned intervention has four main areas.- Enabling Policy and Regulations - Take steps towards conducive remittances policies and regulations, based on strengthened data capacity, that promote access and usage of digital remittances and financial services.- Open Digital Payment Ecosystem - Migrants and beneficiaries have improved access to and increasingly use digital remittances channels to send and receive remittances.- Inclusive Innovation - New business models and technologies for delivering remittances and financial services are tested in the African market and business case established for multiple providers to offer migrant-centric financial products.- Customer Empowerment- Migrant and beneficiaries have the knowledge, skills, and behaviors needed to access and use digital remittances and financial services. The implementation period of the intervention is from September 2019 to December 2022.UNCDF through its Regional Innovation Hub in Dakar and with strong support from the Brussels and New York offices will implement the programme in collaboration with African Institute for Remittance (AIR), based in Nairobi, Kenya, which is AUC's Specialized Technical Institute on remittances.The programme targets Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS), Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD) region of Africa. Together, the programme directly covers 33 countries (60 percent of the AU Member States). Institutionally, both the REC's secretariat and relevant Ministries of the Member States of the three RECs are the beneficiaries of capacity building. In addition, financial institutions of the Member States like central banks, money transfer operators and mobile network operators in the selected RECs will also benefit from the programme. However, the primary beneficiaries of the intervention in the long-term are African migrants and their families at countries of destination and origin.

The overall objective of the intervention is to contribute to regional harmonization of remittances policies and availability of affordable, accessible, reliable, and tailored digital remittances and financial products to migrants towards their economic inclusion, financial resilience, and reduced inequality. Identifying, adapting and enabling access to digital innovation and technology solutions for migrants and their families at countries of origin to impact their livelihoods and facilitate sustained escapes out of poverty. The expected results are at sector, client and stakeholders levels. Client level • Migrants and their families access to digital remittances and financial services increased. • Ability, knowledge, skills and behavior of migrants to access and use digital remittances and financial services improved. Stakeholders level • Inclusive policies and regulations that enable access and usage of digital remittances' services, acknowledged, accepted, adopted and implemented.• Digital infrastructure strengthened and interoperability promoted. • Available accessible, affordable, reliable and appropriate digital remittances' services piloted. • Inclusive and innovative business model and remittances linked financial services tested.• New business model and delivery channel for building digital capabilities and skills of migrants and beneficiaries piloted. Sector level • Remittances and financial service providers benefits from diversified revenues cross-selling opportunity and improved sustainability.• Digital ecosystem with more investment competition and innovations expanded to wider communities. The programme activities are categorized into four work streams. • Work stream one focus on Enabling Policy and Regulations. It is to take steps towards conducive remittances policies and regulations and promote access and usage of digital remittances and financial services.• Work stream two is about Opening Digital Payment. Migrants and beneficiaries have improved access to and increasingly use digital remittances channels to send and receive remittances.• Work stream three focuses on Inclusive Innovation. This work stream is to promote new business models and technologies for delivering remittances and financial services.• Finally, work stream four focuses on Customer Empowerment. It is to increase financial literacy of migrants and their families and required support to get knowledge and skill on digital remittances and financial services.

tag.narrative: 10.5 - Förbättra regleringen och övervakningen av globala finansmarknader och finansinstitut samt stärka genomförandet av sådana regleringar.
10.5 - Improve the regulation and monitoring of global financial markets and institutions and strengthen the implementation of such regulations.

10.b - Encourage official development assistance and financial flows, including foreign direct investment, to States where the need is greatest, in particular least developed countries, African countries, small island developing States and landlocked developing countries, in accordance with their national plans and programmes.

10.b - Uppmuntra offentligt utvecklingsbistånd och finansiella flöden, inklusive utländska direktinvesteringar, till de stater där behovet är som störst, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna, afrikanska länder, små önationer under utveckling samt kustlösa utvecklingsländer, i enlighet med deras nationella planer och program.
10.c - By 2030, reduce to less than 3 per cent the transaction costs of migrant remittances and eliminate remittance corridors with costs higher than 5 per cent.
10.c - Senast 2030 minska transaktionskostnaderna för migranters remitteringar till mindre än 3 procent samt avskaffa remitteringskorridorer där kostnaderna överstiger 5 procent.
